div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE, TUESDAY, JANUARY l0, 1905.
PORT ARTHUR.
JAPANESE NAVAL STATION. SMALL GARRISON ONLY.
div.p: TOKIO, January 9.
Vice-Admiral Sibeyama will probably be placed in charge. The military administration will retain only a small garrison (Reuter.)
Port Arthur, January 9. Twelve naval Attachés have visited the town, and inspected the remains of the Fleet. (Reuter.)

div.head: EFFECT OF FALL IN RUSSIA.
div.p: St. Petersburg, January 9.

The wave of popular emotion which was caused by the surrender of Port Arthur has already subsided. Christmas has created a diversion, and the people are joyously celebrating it in the theatres, music-halls, restaurants, and taverns. On the other hand, the solemn funeral services held at the Isaac and Kasau Cathedrals for the fallen at Port Arthur were poorly attended.
(Reuter.)

div.head: STOESSEL'S IMPRESSIONS.
div.p: Port Arthur, January 9.

Captain Tsunoda, who took to General Stoessel the Mikado's message desiring that the garrison should be well treated, bad a long conversation with General Stoessel, who enquired where General Kuropatkin was. Captain Tsunoda replied that he was on the Sha-Ho. Stoessel was incredulous as he bad not heard of Kuropatkin since the 6th October. He was amazed on hearing that the Baltic Fleet was only at the Cape of Good Hope. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE “ANDROMEDA” INCIDENT.
A MISUNDERSTANDING.
div.p: Tokio, January 9.

The Navy Department regrets the misunderstanding in connection with the ‘‘Andromeda." The commander at Port Arthur acted in accordance with general instructions. The “Andromeda" returned to Wei-bai-wei before the message gratefully accepting the aid had arrived from Tokio. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET.
THE THIRD SQUADRON.
div.p: St. Petersburg, January 9.

The following men-of-war will leave Libau between the 28th inst. and 2nd February in order to join Admiral Rodjestvensky’s squad-dron , Battleship “ Imperator Nicholai," coast-defence ironclads “ General Admiral Araxin," “Admiral Senyavin," “Admiral Ushakoff,” and the cruiser “Vladimir Menomach.” (Reuter.)
Libau, January 9.
Four battleships and a cruiser will sail on the 31st inst to join Admiral Rodjest-vensky’s squadron. (Havas.)
Paris, January 9.
The Temps learns from Copenhagen that Admiral Rodjestvensky will return to Malta to await the third squadron. (Havas.)

div.head: NORTH SEA ENQUIRY COMMISSION.
PRESIDENT ELECTED.
div.p: Paris, January 9.
The North Sea Enquiry Commission has elected Admiral Fournier as president (H.)
Paris, January 9.

A full meeting of the North Sea Enquiry Commission was held to day. It was decided to admit the press. Admiral Fournier was reelected president, Admiral Spaun having withdrawn in favor of him. (Reuter.)

div.head: FOURTH JAPANESE LOAN.
div.p: Tokio, January 9.
It is proposed to shortly float a fourth domestic war loan on the same conditions as the third one. (Reuter.)

div.head: ADMIRAL BIENAIME’S ELECTION.
div.p: Paris, January 9.
Admiral Bienaimé has been elected by the Opposition to replace M. Syveton. He defeated the Ministerialist candidate by 1,272 votes.
(Reuter.)

div.head: FRANCE AND SIAM.
EVACUATION OF CHANTABUN VALLEY.
div.p: Bangkok, January 9.
The evacuation of the Chantabun Valley was completed yesterday. (Reuter.)

div.head: TRADE OF U. K.
div.p: London, January 9.
The increase in the exports, mentioned on the 7th inst., is entirely due to an increase of £l0,000,000 in Lancashire goods and £2,000,000 in woollens. (Reuter.)

div.head: FRENCH CHAMBER.
div.p: Paris, January 9.
M. Doumer is a candidate for the presidency of the Chamber of Deputies. (Havas.)
The British Steam Yacht “ Emerald" left Alexandria harbour last night for an unknown destination.
Appointment.—Mr. Nicola G. Sabbag, 2, rue de la Gare du Caire, Alexandria, has been appointed sole agent lor Egypt lor the firm of Messrs. G. Goulet and Co., of Reims, the well-known wine-growers.

Pay of State Employes.—We hear that the Commission appointed to study the question of the pay of the Government employés will be composed of Mr. Macbeth (president), Harari Pasha, Chitty Bey, Capt. Lyons, and Mr. Brunyate.

Shepheard’s.—The date of Shepheard’s annual grand cotillon ball has been definitely fixed for Monday, 30th instant. About 400 invitations will be issued this week. To-morrow a concert will be given by the full Tsigane Band from 9 to 11 p.m. at Shepheard’s.

Suez Canal.—On the 5th and 6th inst., 31 vessels passed through the Canal, the amount paid in dues being lrs 695,333.78. 21 of the ships were British 1 Austrian, 1 Russian. 1 Turkish, 3 German, 1 Dutch, 1 Danish. The total receipts from 1st to 6th inst. were lrs. 2,316,979.74.

R. Berks.—The return of the three companies of the 2nd Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment from Cairo to Alexandria, which had been postponed, will now take place on Thursday next. The troops will leave Abbassieh riding by a special train leaving at 9.15 a.m. and arriving at Sidi Gaber at 2.25 p.m.

KhartoUm Garrison. — Lieut.-Colonel O. Todd, R.A.M.C, P.M.O. in Egypt, accompanied by Major F. W. Hardy, R.A.M.C, Sanitary Officer, left Cairo on the 7th inst, en route to-Khartoum, to make the annual inspection of barracks and hospital and detachment, R.A.M.C, at that station, returning on completion of the duty.

Commendable Charity.—Mr. S. Hanna, a banker of Assiout, who was on the train at time of the recent accident to the train-de-luxe, got up a subscription in Assiout in aid of the family of the assistant cook, who was killed, and has sent Mr. Tito, general manager in Egypt of the Wagons-Lits Co., a cheque for L.E. 3,616 1/4, to be handed to them in such a way as to guarantee its fair division among the widow and children.

Society Notes.—Paris, the centre of all elegance and all intellectuality, has been spreading its influence more and more in Egyptian society, and especially among the feminine public. The study of languages by the Berlitz system has also been affected. We could mention the names of several ladies of English society learning French and Italian. English, German, Greek, and Arabic are also studied by those of other nationalities. This fashion will soon spread because here pleasure is joined to usefulness. [Advt.]

A Fire broke out early yesterday afternoon in a shop in Toussoun-street, Alexandria. The shop contains a store of chandeliers, lamps, etc., and there was also a considerable quantity of petroleum. It is the property of Count Jacques de Zogheb and was insured for £3,000. The cause is said to be due to a petroleum engine. There was a fire at the same shop three years ago, when it was completely gutted. The shopkeeper is a local subject, of the name of William Guttman. The alarm was given at 1.50 p m. and the engine was on the spot at 1.55 p.m. Owing to the petroleum the blaze and smoke were very great and it was two hours before the Brigade completely mastered it, although eight hoses were kept continually playing.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL.
div.p: Bulkeley, Ramleh.

Ten minutes from Alexandria. First-Class in every respect. Very moderate charges. Bulkeley is the fashionable English quarter. Visitors from Cairo alight at Sidi Gaber Station. 26660-26-5-005 C. AQUILINA, Propriotor.

div.head: ENGLISH IN THE COURTS.
LORD CROMER’S PROPOSAL. THE “ENTENTE CORDIALE."
div.p: The sub-commission, which has recently been studying the question of certain changes which it is proposed to introduce into the Codes now administered by the Mixed Tribunals, having partly completed its labors, the plenary Commission, which is composed of the diplomatic representatives of the Powers, met yesterday.

Lord Cromer announced that he, was about to invite the Egyptian Government to issue a circular to the Powers requesting them to agree to a proposal that English should be admitted as one of the judicial languages recognised by the Mixed Courts, on the same footing as French, Italian, and Arabic, which are at present the only recognised judicial languages. Lord Cromer recommended the proposal to the favorable consideration of his colleagues.
M. de la Bouliniére, the French Consul-General, stated that, when the circular was received, the question would be considered in a very friendly spirit by the French Governmentp
Lord Cromer expressed his thanks for the manner id which his proposal had been received by his French colleague.

It is almost needless to dwell on the importance and necessity of the step Lord Cro-mer is about to take. When we consider the enormous preponderance of the part which the United Kingdom and her colonies play in the commerce of this country, the exclusion from the Mixed Courts of our language becomes an obvious anomaly. As long back as 1897 the committee of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt made strong representations to Lord Cromer, praying him to urge H..M..’s Government to call for the admission of English as one of the recognised languages to be employed in the Mixed Courts from the period of the renewal of their powers for another term of years in February, 1899. Lord Cromer forwarded the letter of the committee to Lord Salisbury. But the time was not yet ripe. The change is one which must be treated diplomatically, as it can only be made with the acquiescence of the fourteen Powers interested in the formation of the Tribunals, and the political status of Egypt did not admit of such a change being then entertained. This state of things has been changed, and the reform can now be undertaken without letting loose a whirlwind of petty- international jealousies.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: In the course of Sunday's reception the Khedive received Saba Pasha, who presented his son-in-law, Mr. Joseph Nahas; Mr. Harry Russell; Sheikh Mohamed Abou Zeid, professor at the Khedivial Law School, who presented his work on personal statics; Maitre Carton de Wiart, who presented Maitre Merybach; Col. Sir Howard Vincent, etc.

div.head: KHEDIVE’S ACCESSION.
div.p: Sunday night’s festivities continued to a late hour, and a special performance was given at the Khedivial Opera House at which H. H. the Khedive was present. His Highness’s entry was the occasion of an enthusiastic demonstration.

On returning from the review in the afternoon H. H. the Khedive ordered H.E. Ahmed Zeki Pasha to telegraph to the Sirdar his congratulations on the fine appearance and martial bearing of the troops. An order of the day will be issued by the Sirdar giving the army the text of his Highness’s message.

To our description of the review we should like to add the fact that the Khedive personally expressed to Lewa Lord Edward Cecil Pasha, who was in command, his great satisfaction at the discipline and manoeuvring powers of the troops, and especially of the cavalry, whose riding and drill were praised on all sides.

div.head: ACCESSION DAY HONORS.
div.p: Owing to abundance of matter we have been obliged to hold over until to-morrow the publication of the Accession Day honors. The Khedive has conferred the following decorations :—
Osmanieh: Grand Cordon, 1st Class. Abani Pasha, Mr. Corbett, Sir R. Wingate.
Medjidieh : Grand Cordon, 1st Class. Ibrahim Naguib Pasha, Sir E Zohrab Pasha, Mr. Mitchell Innes, Count de Vauvineux.

div.head: JUDGE ASSESSORS.
div.p: The following gentlemen have been elected Judge-Assessors for commercial cases in the Mixed Courts at Alexandria for the present year. The numbers after each name signify the votes obtained :—

Messrs. Michel Sinadino, 110, Ambroise Zervoudachi, 110, Theocharis Cotzikas, 109, Emanuele Stross, 109, H. P. Kingham, 108. Georges Caram, 107, Henri Nahman, 106, Ambroise A. Ralli, 106, Dante Rieti, 105, Richard C. Abdy, 104, Emanuel Benachi,104, Paul Fenderl 104, Paul Hanlohser 104, Fre-deric Hess 104, Oscar Rothacker 104, Henri Bindernagel 103, Ernest Mallison 103, Luigi Stagni 103, Sidney Carver 102, Auguste Frenay 101, Louis Escoffier 100, Adolphe Stross 96, Charles Schoeller 93, Léon Schuler 64.
GRAND HOTEL BONNARD, ALEXANDRIA 8a. PER DA, WINE INCLUDED 22888.16.7.905

div.head: THE RUSSIAN SQUADRON.
ARRIVAL AT PORT SAID. JAPANESE GOVERNMENT’S PROTEST.
div.p: (from our own Correspondent).
Port Said, Monday, 9 p.m.

Admiral Botrovosky's squadron, from Suda Bay, consisting of four cruisers and three destroyers, will be off the port at 4 a.m. to-morrow. The vessels will be moored at buoys 6, 7, 8, and 9, and the three south berths of the rive Asie.
There are no orders yet for passing through the Canal.
No store-ships are with the fleet.
The Japanese Government has lodged a protest against the supply of provisions or fresh water, which, it will be remembered, were supplied to the last fleet
The ships will be guarded by patrol boats, as before.

div.head: THE ROYAL VISIT.
div.p: The Duke and Duchess of Connaught are leaving Lisbon to-morrow on H.M.S. “Essex” and will arrive at Cadiz on the following day. Their itinerary afterwards will be as follows:— Leave Cadiz 12th or 13th ; arrive Gibraltar 14th, leave 17th ; arrive Algiers 18th, leave 20th ; arrive Tunis 21st, leave 22nd; arrive Alexandria 23rd. Their Royal Highnesses are expected to remain in Egypt about three weeks.

div.head: ABOUKIR COMPANY, LIMITED.
11 % INTERIM DIVIDEND.
div.p: The Directors of the Aboukir Company, Limited, have resolved that out of the estimated profits for the year ending 31st December, 1904, an interim dividend be paid on ordinary shares of 10s. 10 3/4d. per share, being the balance of arrears of dividend to 31st December, 1903.
As the shares are £5, this interim dividend is 11 %.

div.head: HELOUAN.
div.p: The Grand Hotel, Helouan, is quite full already and there are many arrivals daily. A number of rooms bare already been booked by visitors now up the Nile. It has been arranged that the famous Bracale Orchestra will play several times at the Grand Hotel, in the afternoon on the terrace and during dinner, as well as for small dances. A beautiful open-air tent saloon has been lately erected on the terrace of the Grand and is the admiration of all visitors.

The Bath Establishment has lately been more frequented than usual, and the famous Helouan Baths are recommended specially to people suffering from gout and rheumatism. The strong sulphur water and the massages given by the experienced masseurs and masseusses do ever so much good to all sufferers, and visitors to Egypt should not fail to pay a visit to the Bath Establishment at Helouan.

The golf links is much visited by all keen golfers, and the professional Fulford has a great deal to do in giving lessons to those desirous either of learning the royal and ancient game or becoming perfect golfers.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
SIBERIA.
div.p: Giordano’s opera Siberia was produced the first time in Egypt at the above theatre on Saturday evening and was not received with any very great demonstration of enthusiasm by the large audience present. This is scarcely to be wondered at when the peculiarly depressing nature of the drama is taken into consideration. Two acts of Siberian penal settlements and chains are scarcely calculated to make the ordinary theatre-goer feel particularly lively or demonstrative. Certain passages in the music remind one of Germania and the effects arrived at are occasionally somewhat similar. The opera, however, requires a second bearing to fully appreciate the ideas intended to be conveyed by the composer. That the work is a very meritorious one is without question. The orchestra on many occasions absolutely drowned the voices of the artistes, who did their best, if the expression may be so used, to make themselves heard above the crash and din of drums, brass, and cymbals. Signorina Amelia Pinto was in splendid voice and gave an admirable interpretation of the exceedingly trying role of Stephana, being rewarded with several handsome bouquets. Signor Giraud gave a fairly good rendering of the part of Vassili, but bis voice is not sufficiently robust to stand him in good stead in an opera like Siberia. As Gleby, Signor Nani made a good impression, and gave, as he always does, an excellent interpretation of the character. Sig. Tisci Ru-bini and the other artistes were equally good in their respective roles. The choruses were particularly well rendered, and both male and female members of the chorus entered fully into their supposed miserable lot in life. The staging was excellent, and the costuming perfect in every way.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner "Rameses" arrived at Liverpool yesterday morning.
The S.S. "Asiatic Prince" arrived at Manchester from Alexandria on Sunday Last.
The S.S. "Grecian Prince" left Manchester on Monday, with passengers and general cargo, for Malta and Alexandria.
H.H. Prince Djemil Pasha Toussoun and General Ahmed Pasha Djelal-ed-din are expected back from up-river next Thursday..
Sir William Garstin will probably return from the Sudan on the 16th inst..

Our Edfou correspondent writes: — The P. W. D. steamer “Dendara' arrived at Edfou on Saturday with the following party on board: Mr. Vincent Corbett, the Financial Adviser, and Mrs. Corbett, Mr. Anthony, of the State Lands Dept, Mr. Richmond, of the Tanzim, and Mr. Quibell, of the Antiquities Dept., who disembarked in order to pay a visit to this interesting village. They were cordially received and accompanied by the Mamour and other principal officials to the great Temple of Horus, where they passed a pleasant hour. They climbed to the top of the tower, where they bad a charming view of the valley at sunset They afterwards returned to the steamer, where they spent the night, and at peep of day they set off for a visit to Kom-Ombo whence they will go on to Assouan.
We hear that Mr. MacGillivray, of the National Bank, leaves this week for Mombasa to enjoy three weeks’ big-game shooting in Somaliland..
M. and Mme. Pierre Lebaudy, of Paris, with a big party, including M. Luzarche d'Azoy and Comte de Morsey, arrived at the Savoy Hotel yesterday..
Leave of absence in extension, for the recovery of his health, has been granted to Major B. W. Longhurst, R.A.M.C., from 14th inst. to July 13..
Mr. H. Scott-Leslie, the well-known entertainer, has arrived at Alexandria and intends giving a few recitals here..

The following passengers left Cairo by the “Amenartas" for the Nile trip yesterday :— Mr. and Mrs. R. Lemk, Capt. and Mrs. Hiltrheimer, Miss D. Garstang, Mrs. B. R. Headlam, Miss Majendie, Miss Cochran, Baron Munk, Mr. and Mrs. Otto G. Wolff, Mr. and Mrs. Schwerin, Mr. Schwerin, Jr, Mr. Fred Krumm, Mr. D. R. Perry, Mr. F. T. Dwyer, Mr. W. V. Aldridge, Major Scott Murray..

The following passengers by the P.S. “Ama sis” leave Assiout to-day: Field Marshal Lt Ferd. and Mrs. Siedler, Mr. A. Pedro Andrade, Mr. Max Thomas, Mr. Dietrich, Dr. Max Tho-roy, Mr. George Gladstone, Mme. Emilie Tho-rey, Mme. Lisa Dieckhoff, Dr. R. Weiss, Dr. Otto Seehagen, Mrs. Rosetta Joseph, Miss Elise Joseph, Miss Joseph..

Amongst the latest arrivals at the Eastern Exchange Hotel, Port-Said are Lord and Lady Emusmore, Mr. S. H. Nichols, Mr. A.W. Ellis, Col. J. Huddlestone, Mr. G. Cookson, Mr. F. E. Mason, Mr. and Mrs. A. Taylor, Mr. J. W. Clark, Mr. M. J. R. Ceclow, Mr. and Mrs. E. Batis, Mr. H. I. Greaves, Mr. and Mrs. J. Fisher, Miss Meade, Lt. Col. Sir Curzon Wyllie and Lady Wyllie, Mr. E. E. Cooner, Mr. J. O. Mullings, Mr. S. H. Nichols, Mr. H. P. Wasenkagen.

ARRIVALS>

WINDSOR HOTEL Largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel in Alexandria. Facing the sea, Central Position. Under English management 01-11-904.

div.head: DEATH OF LOUISE MICHEL
div.p: Marseilles, January 9.
Louise Michel is dead. (Havas.)

The remarkable woman who has just passed away, and wbo was often so prominent as a French revolutionary leader, was born at Vron- coart in 1830, and first distinguished herself by her poetical and musical talents, which were recognised and encouraged by Victor Hugo. In 1860 she opened a school in the Quartier Montmartre, Paris; and in 1870 took an active part with the revolutionary Commune, and was made prisoner; and though she eloquently defended herself before the judges, she was sentenced to transportation for life. On the amnesty to political prisoners in 1880 she returned to Paris; and, continuing to take part in Communist assemblies, she was re-imprisoned in 1883, and again in 1886. As an Anarchist, she frequently addressed Hyde Park meetings, and as an authoress she was well-known, having written many revolutionary publications and a novel entitled “The Microbes of Society.".

div.head: IN HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S CONSULAR COURT AT CAIRO.
PROBATE JURISDICTION.
div.p: In the Goods of
EDMUND KELLY DE WILTON BEY Deceased.
Pursuant to Act of Parliament 22nd and 23rd Victoria Cap. 35, Section 29,

Notice is here by given that all persons and Creditors having any claims or demands upon or against the Estate of Edmund Kelly De Wilton Bey, late of Suez, Egypt, deceased (who died at Cairo on the 25th day of March 1903, and Probate of whose Will dated the 2nd day of March 1903 was granted by the above-mentioned Court on the 19th day of February 1904 to the undersigned L. Carton De Wiart, as Attorney of Signora Georgina Paretto, the Executrix therein named) are hereby required to send particulars of their claim or demands to the undersigned on or before the 10th day of February 1905, and Notice is hereby given that after that day the Executrix will proceed to distribute the assets of the deceased having regard only to the claims of which she shall then have notice and will not be liable for the Assets or any part thereof so distributed to any person of whose debt or claim she shall not then have rereived notice.
Dated this 9th day of January 1905.
L. Carton De Wiart, Wairt,
Legal Practitioner for the Executrix.

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIARE
UNE CAUSE RETENTISSANTE Le procès Bustros contre les courtiers d'Arixandrle- et la Bourse Khédiviale
div.p: (Audience d'hier de la Chambre Commerciale )

Rappelons brièvement l'origine du procès intenté par M.M. Bustros frères à la Société de la Bourse Khédiviale et à l’Association des Courtiers : M.M. Albert et Edouard Bustros, s’étant présentés pour faire partie de l’Associa­tion dos Courtiers d'Alexandrie, s’étaient vus refuser leur candidature par un ballottage. Cette Association, en effet, composée de 74 membres, admet le vote comme dans un club ; et c’est là le premier grief de M.M. Bustros. Us protestent contre cétte adoption des mœurs d’un club pour un marché public; ils se plaignent qu'un candi­dat ayant peu de fortune soit reçu plus volon­tiers qu’un autre plus riche qui pourrait créer & l’Association une concurrence redoutable ; ils protestent contre l’atteinte partie par cet exclusivisme à la liberté des transactions com­merciales, exclusivisme qui est contraire à l’es: prit et à la lettre de la loi mixte.
Nous donnons ci-dessous, aussi impartiale; ment que possible, un résumé des plaidoiries de divers avocats devant la Chambre Commerciale h l'audience d’hier.

Mes Le Moine et Carton do Wiart ont dé­fendu les intérêts de MM. Bustros ; ils ont exposé que l’association des courtiers, tello qu'elle fonctionne à Alexandrie constitue un véritable accaparement du marché à terme égyptien, que cette association est dépourvue de toute existence légale et juridique, qu'elle n'est aucunement autorisée ni par la loi ni pàr un décret et qu'ainsi c'est arbitrairement quelle impose en fait non seulement à ses associés mais également aux tierces personnes les ar­bitraires prescriptions d'un règlement qu'elle a élaboré dans un intérêt purement égoïste et fiscal. La meilleure preuve en est qu’alors qu’il est constant que l'iutérêt public serait assuré par l’admission dans ce groupement de courtiers de maisons aussi riches que respecta­bles, telles que celle de MM. Bustros, la dite association ne manque pas de blackbouler pa­reille candidature parce que les nouveaux venus pourraient enlever à ses anciens mem­bre le bénéfice de courtages importants. Au surplus, cette association ne mérite guère la sympathie de la justice, puisque ses membres ne sont liés par aucun lieu de solidarité au profit de la clientèle et du public. Donc, telle qu elle fonctionne par un prétendu règlement» repoussé tant par la loi que par la (jour d’Ap­pel Mixte, l’association porte atteinte au prin- cice de la liberté commerciale et porte préju­dice à M.M. Bustros frères. Me Le Moine invo­que hautement la grande autorité qui s'attache au très remarquable ouvrage de M. le Conseiller Vercamer ; il en cite des extraits des plus il téressants. Vainement les avocats de l’association soutiennent que celle-ci est et reste chez elle et que conséquemment elle a le droit de refuser tout candidat qui $e présente.

Me Lemoine leur répond que les droits indi­viduels se limitent mutuellement, et qu’un acte, même licite en soi, acquiert un caractère délic­tueux dès qu'il porte atteinte au droit d'autrui. Il est, en effet, démontré en la cause que le système d'accaparement, dont l'association s'est rendue coupable, empêche MM. Bustros d’exer­cer librement et normalement la profession de courtiers. Me Le Moine explique, eu effet, qu’il esp impossible à un courtier non associé de faire des affairas à la Bourse Khédiviale. Un exemple d'actualité démoDtre, dit-il, à quel point le despotisme de l'association est intolé­rable : la Banque Impériale Ottomane avait été chargée hier lundi par M. le président du Tribunal d’Alexandrie de vendra 60 actions de la Banque Nationale ; M. le Directeur du dit établissement, ne faisant pas partie de l’as­sociation des courtiers, n’a pu réaliser lui-même le mandat, de justice dont il avait été investi; il a du rester hors de la corbeille et charger un courtier do l’association de faire l’opération dont s’agit Me Le Moine conclut que rien ne saurait mieux démontrer le caractère illégal et arbitraire du prétendu règlement de l’associa­tion des courtiers. MM. Bustros, dont la haute respectabilité n'est contestée par personne, viennent demander protection à la justice et l’application à l’encontre de l’association de l’article 72 du code de commerce.

Me Palagi, au nom de la Bourse Khédiviale, mise en cause par MM. Bustros frères, soutient qu’en ce qui concerne sa cliente, la demande est irrecevable, parce que le contrat constitutif de la Bourse Khédiviale, concédé par le Gou­vernement Egyptien, demeure étranger aux demandeurs qui n’y étaient pas partie. Au fond, dit-il, la Bourse Khédiviale a exploité les avantages qui lui ont été concédés par le Gou­vernement en 1683 dans des conditions non critiquables.

Me X. Socoli, au nom de l’Association, soutient que la demande de MM. Bustros, est dénuée de tout fondement, que l’Association a parfaitement le droit de se réglementer comme elle l’entend, qu'elle se considère comme étant dégagée de toute oUbligation d’accepter de nouveaux courtiers et qu’en somme son organisation, quoiqu’on ait dit Me Le Moine, îi’empècbe pas les courtiers Kfceé d’exercer leur profession. Il ajoute que la demande apparaît encore comme irrecevable a un àutre point de vue, & savoir quelle aurait pour, objet d’inviter le tribunal K légiférer en Pétât de silence delà loi aur la matière.

Me Carton de Wiart répond d’abord à Me Palagî en lui rappelant un arrêt Intervenu on 1893 an profit de la Compagnie du Canal de duquel il réaulte que les tiers ont le droit indeniable d'examiner et de discuter les con

cessions accordées par le Gouvemement a des personnes quelconques. Donc l'administration de la Bourse Khédiviale, qui est en train dp détourner de sa dèetinatio^ première le local qui lui a été vendu avec affectation spécial® à un marduf public, a manqué aux obligations qui lui trient imposées par le Gouvernement; soit de uWorder à qui que ce soit un traita ment do faveur, comme elle le fait au profit dt l’association.

En ce qui concerne les moyens présentes par Mo Socoli, Me Carton de Wiart confirme tout ce qui a été plaidé partie Le Moine. Il ajoute qu’il est plaisant d’entendre los courtiers asso­ciés inviter M.M. Bustros h exercer fa pro­fession do courtier en dehors de l’associaction, alors que les règlements de cette asr sociation ne permettront jamais aux dits MM. Bustros de , trouver la contre-parti e exigée par 1a loi et 1a jurisprudence, étant donné qu'en fait les courtiers associés se sont défendus de traiter avec un courtier libre. Me Carton de Wiàrt termine en disant que ce n’est pas le tribunal qui va légi­férer, mais qu'au contraire le tribunal jugera que c’est l’association qui a légiféré, alors que pour ce faire il lui eut fallu l’autorisation du gouvernement et des puissances. L’association | a trouvé plus simple de se substituer à cet en; ! semble de pouvoirs.

Me Colucci réplique qu auoun de argument présentés, par Me Le Moine ot Me Carton de Wiart ne l’a frappé, ni ne l’intérwse; il affirme que ces 2 susnommés confrères oût plaidé i; j côté de fa question et, fa. preuve en est, dit-il; que du moment, que Me. Le Moine déefarq j l’association inexistante il n’y pas lieu dp l'attaquçr et de demander une coqdampatioq •contre elle. D'ailleurs, le règlement no vise que les associés ; les tiers auxquels il n’est pap opposable n’ont rien à y voir et l’association qui a’est organisée à fa Bourse Khédiviale, comme elle aurait pu s’organiser ailleurs en .toute liberté, est absolument dans sou droit eu refusant la candidature de qui que oe soit, même celle de Mit Bustros. L’association est exclu4.vpn;fflat.chej elle dans los oorbpilles,qui sont installées h la Bourse Khédivaio—libre h MMl BuVtros.de circuler comme il leur plaira dans le surplus du local Me Colucci explique que le système de la loi mixte au sujet des courtiers est inspirée d’une, ancienne loi belge de 1874, laquelle n’impose aucune entrave a la liberté des courtier» se constituant en syndicat, ‘Il indique que les statuts de l’association des courtiers sont, pour ainsi dire, copiés sur oeux -dos conlissiers de Paris. Il termine en sonli- gnant l’étrangeté de fa demande de MM. Bastros qui veulent entrer à tont prix dans, [ une association qui est et demeure fermée.

Me Le Moine réplique que, s’il est vrai que l’association des courtiers n’existe pas en droit et qu’h ce point de vue il l’ignore, il est bien obligé do la connaître en /ait, puitquo par son règlement elle no se contente pas de lier les associés, mais qu’elle rend obligatoires an préjudice des tiers les prescriptions de son pré­tendu règlement ; il en résuite que personne no peut faire d’opérations on Bourse sans subir obligatoirement l’entremise des courtiers, il fait remarquer h Me Colucci que les courtiers d’Alexandrie ont bien copié les règlements des coulissiers de Paris niais, ce qui est inac­ceptable, c’est qu’er vertu de règlements n'inté«î.ssant qne des coulissiere, les mem­bres de l’association s’attribuent indûment les prérogatives de fa Compagnie des Agents de Change do Paris ; ils sortent d’autant plus de leur ride qu’ils s’empressent de mettre de côté fa clause de solidarité qui unit les agents le change de Paris et qui assure au public une. garantie collective, telle qu’aucune faillite ou déconfiture d’agents de change ne peut léser les intérêts de 1a clientèle d’un des membres do fa Compagnie. Me Le Moine termine en rappelant tant b 1a Bourse Khédiviale qufa l’association des courtiers qn’un seul texte légal existe en fa cause, il savoir les accords consti­tutifs en 1883 de 1a Bourse Khédiviale et que de traitement de faveur et d'exclusivisme dont profite l’association est illégal et illicite, que donc le seul texte légal so trouve violé. Il échet dono de rappeler l’administration de fa Bourse Khédiviale et ses amis, les courtiers, au respect de fa convention passée avec le ’ Gouvernement Egyptien.

div.head: Concert Toselli
div.p: Dimancee a eu lieu le concert donné par M. Enrico Tosell», disciple de G. Martucci, un des pins grands symphonistes de notre époque.

L’exécution impeccable des divers numéros dn programme qui comportent des difficultés techniques presque insurmontables ont révélé en M. Toselli nn virtuose plein de talent et d’nndoigté musclé aussi-fin que délicat.

Mais c’est surtout dans l’interprétation fidèle des chefs d’œnvre de oette musique classique dont les bonnes traditions semblent disparaître, quoiqu’on en dise, de jour en jour davantage, qu’excelle ce pianiste d’élite, la Nocturne Op. 15 et fa Polonais Op. 53 de Chopin, en particulier, qui avaient perdu en leui autedr le meilleur interprète, ont retrouvé en l’flèvo do M. Martacoi, un exécutant hors ligne.

div.head: Eastern Telegraph Coy., Ltd.
div.p: Average Time

div.head: SUICIDE FROM DESPAIR.
THE INQUEST ON MR. BENSILUM.
div.p: The inquest on the late Mr. A. Bensilum was continued yesterday morning at the British Consulate, Cairo.

Herz Bey, called as a witness, took the oath and stated that the deceased was employed in his office from early in 1897 to November 29, 1904. Deceased was an architect working under the Bureau du Comite des Monuments Arabes. Witness had been ill, and alter returning from Helouan on the 26th November last, found a letter from deceased tendering his resignation. He knew of no reason for this. He had received two letters from the deceased in which he excused himself for non attendance at the of­fice, giving various excuses, followed by a formal letter of resignation. He saw the de­ceased, who gave no reason and merely said that he was going to Alexandria.

Questioned by the jury, witness stated that he bad not been altogether satisfied with de­ceased's work, and quoted several cases in which he had been forced to reprimand him for omissions and negligence of orders. On the last occasion deceased said he would comply with the spirit if not the letter of his in­structions. He had previously written to Dr. Sierra, an uncle of the deceased, more than once. On this occasion, when he returned to the office, which had been in deceased’s charge during absence of witness, certain things had not been done, and the clerks said they would resign if deceased was put in charge again. After bringing deceased’s conduct before the committee he wrote to Dr. Sierra, saying that he wished to speak to him about a relation. In reply to the question as to who it was, contained in Dr. Siena’s answering letter, be wrote and put the facts before him, but on receiving deceased’s letter tendering his re­signation he wired to Dr. Sierra to consider witness’s second letter as null. His report to the committee and complaints to Dr. Sierra could not have been known to deceased before be gave his resignation. Deceased’s salary was L.E. 22 ; he began at L.E. 13.

The jury brought in a verdict of suicide from despair, on which Mr. Alban, who was presiding over the inquest, asked them to consider whether deceased was compos mentis or not when he committed suicide.
The jury retired for consideration and gave a verdict of “suicide while deceased was not responsible for his actions, owing to despair at his non-success in his profession.”

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive left Koubbeh Palace onThurs day evening in order to make a tour of inspec­tion of his estates on the Ismailia Canal.

div.head: OUR ROYAL VISITORS.
div.p: Prince Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden and Norway and suite are due to arrive at Alexan­dria on Monday next at noon by the North German Lloyd’s S.S. "Hohenzollern.” His Royal Highness’s suite includes the Lord High Chamberlain, Baron von Ralamb, and Colonel Swerre.

The Prince will be welcomed on board by Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, Governor of Alexandria, who will represent the Khedive. Mr. Belinfante-Ostberg, Swedish and Norwegian Consul General and Diplomatic Agent, is coming down from Cairo in order to go on board with Mr. Henry Barker, Swedish and Norwegian Consul at Alexandria, to meet the Prince, who will leave for Cairo probably at 4.25 p.m.
The Khedive has placed his saloon carriage at the disposal of the Prince for the journey to Cairo.

div.head: A NEW EGYPTIAN COMPANY.
div.p: In the course of next week Messrs. E. Mallison & Co., of Alexandria, will offer the shares of the Egyptian Investment and Agency, Limited, for public subscription in Egypt. The capital of this company’ will be £200,000, divided into 200,000 shares of £1 each, with power to increase to £1,000,000 upon resolu­tion of the board. The directors intend to invite subscriptions in London and Egypt for 200,000 shares at £1 each at par. Payments must bo made as follows : 2s. on application and 3s. on allotment, and the balance when required in calls of 5s. each at intervals of not less than three calendar months. The board of directors will be composed of Sir Frederic Fryer (chairman,), Major Villiers, Mr. Sellon, director of the London Electric Supply Coy., Mr. Frank Owen, Mr. Mack, managing director of the Nile Valley Co., and Mr. Ernest Cable, of the firm of Bird & Co., of London and Calcutta. Mr. R. Abdy will be managing direc­tor in Egypt, and Mr. Eugene Mieli manager in Egypt.

The prospectuses are due to arrive at Alex­andria from Europe in all probability on Tues­day next and will be obtainable from Messrs. E. Mallison & Co. and Messrs. Salinas Bro­thers. The list will probably open and close on Thursday next The object of the company is to undertake general- financial business in Egypt, and with the wide local experience and high reputation which both the managing director and manager in Egypt enjoy, there is every prospect of a successful future before the company.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner “Menes" sailed from Liver­pool yesterday afternoon and is due here about the 27th inst., with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
